edu.cpp.cs.cs141.GECLYfinalproj

Class ConsoleInterface

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.cpp.cs.cs141.GECLYfinalproj.UserInterface
      • edu.cpp.cs.cs141.GECLYfinalproj.ConsoleInterface

  • public class ConsoleInterface
extends UserInterface
    This class represents the console based interface which will involve console elements like the Scanner and System.out.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private java.io.PrintStream systemOutput
      The PrintWriter that will be used for output (works the same as System.out).
      private boolean unicodeEnabled
      Whether or not output should use Unicode, as opposed to plain, ASCII characters.
      private java.util.Scanner userInput
      This field represents the Scanner that the user will use to interact with the UI.

    • Field Detail

      • userInput

        private java.util.Scanner userInput
        This field represents the Scanner that the user will use to interact with the UI.

      • systemOutput

        private java.io.PrintStream systemOutput
        The PrintWriter that will be used for output (works the same as System.out). Note that we will need to make considerations for Unicode support by using an OutputStreamWriter with the right encoding as a first argument. If that doesn't work at runtime, we can default to ASCII by setting unicodeEnabled.

      • unicodeEnabled

        private boolean unicodeEnabled
        Whether or not output should use Unicode, as opposed to plain, ASCII characters.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConsoleInterface

        public ConsoleInterface()
        Initializes this object's userInput, systemOutput, and whether unicodeEnabled.

    • Method Detail

      • initializeSystemOutput

        private void initializeSystemOutput()
        This is a helper method for this class's constructor. The default PrintStream System.out does not always support Unicode by default (particularly on Windows). If we don't need unicode, then this is fine and we can rely on System.out. Otherwise, we attempt to enable a new OutputStreamWriter with the proper encoding. TODO: Make sure that this work is actually necessary in some cases.

      • showMessage

        public void showMessage(java.lang.String message)
        This method will print a method in the console.

      • displayMenu

        public int displayMenu(java.lang.String[] choices)
        Creates a menu based off of an array of strings, and returns the array index of the string stat was selected.
        Parameters:
        choices - the options that will be given to the player //@param query the text to prompt the player with
        Returns:
        the array index of the choice that was selected

      • displayMenu

        public boolean displayMenu()
        Displays a yes/no choice to the player, and returns the result as a boolean.
        Returns:
        true if 'yes', false if 'no'

      • getInt

        private int getInt(int min,
                   int max)
        Waits for the user to enter a valid number that is inside the specified range, then returns the result. Used for letting the player select menu choices.
        Parameters:
        min - the smallest number that will be accepted
        max - the largest number that will be accepted
        Returns:
        the int that the player selected

      • displayGrid

        public void displayGrid(Direction direction)
        This method displays the game board in the console. It will display the actual locations of all items or the visible state of the game based on whether debugging mode is on or not. Currently you must manually define the direction player is looking on line 183, but that will change once the actual game loop is implemented.
        Specified by:
        displayGrid in class UserInterface
        Parameters:
        direction - that the user wishes to look in

      • getObjectRep

        private java.lang.String getObjectRep(Locatable l)
        Decides what one square should look like, based on the contents of the Grid at this position.
        Parameters:
        l - The locatable to get the representation of
        Returns:
        A string representing the entire square the object resides in

      • getObjectRep

        private java.lang.String getObjectRep()
        Decides what one square should look like, under the assumption that the square cnnot be seen.
        Returns:
        A string representing a blank square

      • startGame

        public void startGame()
        Description copied from class: UserInterface
        This method starts the game and is called from the Main method. It creates the engine, something that should be done the same in all subclasses. Subclasses should call Super() before implementing their methods.
        Overrides:
        startGame in class UserInterface
